member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Controls.CompositeContentShape
member.summary: Provides a base class of a composite shape that derives from and implements .
member.remarks:
implements interface, and supports rendering a geometry similar to , but the geometry can be rendered outside the layout boundary.
A typical implementation has a customized default template in generic.xaml which template-binds most shape properties to a . It should also extend the property to customize the appearance of the .
This class also supports showing content together with the shape.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySourceParameters
member.summary: Provides an interface to describe the parameters of a Shape.
member.remarks: This interface is the data for communication between Shape and GeometrySource. Typically, a concrete implementation of IShape will implement this interface and pass it into GeometrySource.UpdateGeometry(), which will then consume the shape as a read-only data provider.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IShape
member.summary: Provides the necessary interface to define a Shape. Both primitive and composite shapes need to match this interface, although they might derive from different types of FrameworkElement.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentHelper.ArcToBezierHelper.ArcToBezier(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Double,System.Double,System.Windows.Point[]@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: ArcToBezier, computes the Bezier approximation of an arc.
member.remarks:
This utility computes the Bezier approximation for an elliptical arc as it is defined in the SVG arc spec. The ellipse from which the arc is carved is axis-aligned in its own coordinates, and defined there by its x and y radii. The rotation angle defines how the ellipse's axes are rotated relative to the x axis. The start and end points define one of 4 possible arcs; the sweep and large-arc flags determine which one of these arcs will be chosen.
Returning cPieces = 0 indicates a line instead of an arc cPieces = -1 indicates that the arc degenerates to a point

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentHelper.ArcToBezierHelper.GetArcAngle(System.Windows.Point,System.Windows.Point,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Gets the number of Bezier arcs, and sine/cosine of each.
member.remarks: This is a private utility used by ArcToBezier. Breaks the arc into pieces so that no piece will span more than 90 degrees. The input points are on the unit circle.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentHelper.ArcToBezierHelper.GetBezierDistance(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: GetBezierDistance returns the distance as a fraction of the radius.
member.remarks:
Get the distance from a circular arc's end points to the control points of the Bezier arc that approximates it, as a fraction of the arc's radius.
Since the result is relative to the arc's radius, it depends strictly on the arc's angle. The arc is assumed to be of 90 degrees or less, so the angle is determined by the cosine of that angle, which is derived from rDot = the dot product of two radius vectors. We need the Bezier curve that agrees with the arc's points and tangents at the ends and midpoint. Here we compute the distance from the curve's endpoints to its control points.
Since we are looking for the relative distance, we can work on the unit circle. Place the center of the circle at the origin, and put the X axis as the bisector between the 2 vectors. Let a be the angle between the vectors. Then the X coordinates of the 1st and last points are cos(a/2). Let x be the X coordinate of the 2nd and 3rd points. At t=1/2 we have a point at (1,0). But the terms of the polynomial there are all equal:
(1-t)^3 = t*(1-t)^2 = t^2*(1-t) = t^3 = 1/8,
so from the Bezier formula there we have:
1 = (1/8) * (cos(a/2) + 3x + 3x + cos(a/2)),
hence
x = (4 - cos(a/2)) / 3
The X difference between that and the 1st point is:
DX = x - cos(a/2) = 4(1 - cos(a/2)) / 3.
But DX = distance / sin(a/2), hence the distance is
dist = (4/3)*(1 - cos(a/2)) / sin(a/2).
Rather than the angle a, we are given rDot = R^2 * cos(a), so we multiply top and bottom by R:
dist = (4/3)*(R - Rcos(a/2)) / Rsin(a/2)
and use some trig: ________________ cos(a/2) = \/(1 + cos(a)) / 2 ______________________ R*cos(a/2) = \/(R^2 + R^2 cos(a)) / 2 ________________ = \/(R^2 + rDot) / 2
Let A = (R^2 + rDot)/2. ____________________ R*sin(a/2) = \/R^2 - R^2 cos^2(a/2) _______ = \/R^2 - A
so: _ 4 R - \/A dist = - * ------------ 3 _______ \/R^2 - A
History: 5/29/2001 MichKa Created it.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentHelper.ArcToBezierHelper.AcceptRadius(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double@)
member.summary: Returns false if the radius is too small compared to the chord length (returns true on NaNs) radius is modified to the value that is accepted.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.BezierCurveFlattener
member.summary: A utility class to flatten Bezier curves.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.BezierCurveFlattener.FlattenCubic(System.Windows.Point[],System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Windows.Point},System.Boolean,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Double})
member.summary: Flattens a Bezier cubic curve and adds the resulting polyline to the third parameter.
member.param: The four Bezier cubic control points.
The maximum distance between two corresponding points on the true curve and on the flattened polyline. Must be strictly positive.
Where to add the flattened polyline.

True to skip the first control point when adding the flattened polyline. Where to add the value of the Bezier curve parameter associated with each of the polyline vertices. If is empty, the first control point and its associated parameter are always added.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.BezierCurveFlattener.FlattenQuadratic(System.Windows.Point[],System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Windows.Point},System.Boolean,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Double})
member.summary: Flattens a Bezier quadratic curve and adds the resulting polyline to the third parameter. Uses degree elevation for Bezier curves to reuse the code for the cubic case.
member.param: The three Bezier quadratic control points.
The maximum distance between two corresponding points on the true curve and on the flattened polyline. Must be strictly positive.
Where to add the flattened polyline.

Whether to skip the first control point when adding the flattened polyline. Where to add the value of the Bezier curve parameter associated with each of the polyline vertices. If is empty, the first control point and its associated parameter are always added.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentData
member.summary: A Tuple data structure for PathSegment and the corresponding StartPoint.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData
member.summary: Represents a polyline with a list of connecting points. A closed polygon is represented by repeating the first point at the end. The differences, normals, angles, and lengths are computed on demand.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Windows.Point})
member.summary: Constructs a polyline with two or more points.

members.member: The forward difference vector of polyline. Points[i] + Differences[i] = Points[i+1]

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.SmoothNormal(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compute the normal vector of given location (lerp(index, index+1, fraction). If the location is within range of cornerRadius, interpolate the normal direction.
member.param: The range of normal smoothless. If zero, no smoothness and return the exact normal on index.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.IsClosed
member.summary: The polyline is closed when the first and last points are repeated.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Count
member.summary: The count of points in this polyline.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.TotalLength
member.summary: The total arc length of this polyline.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Points
member.summary: The point array of this polyline.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Lengths
member.summary: The length between line segments, Points[i] to Points[i+1].

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Normals
member.summary: The list of normal vectors for each segment. Normals[i] is the normal of segment p[i] to p[i + 1]. Normals[N-1] == Normals[N-2].

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Angles
member.summary: The list of Cos(angle) between two line segments on point p[i]. Note: The value is cos(angle) = Dot(u, v). Not in degrees.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.AccumulatedLength
member.summary: The list of accumulated length from points[i] to points[0].

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation
member.summary: The data structure to communicate with the PathMarch algorithm.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.GetPoint(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Windows.Point})
member.summary: Gets the interpolated position of this MarchLocation on a given point list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.GetNormal(Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData,System.Double)
member.summary: Get the interpolated normal direction of this MarchLocation on a given normal vector list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.GetArcLength(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Gets the arc length of this MarchLocation to the start of the entire polyline.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Reason
member.summary: The reason why this location is sampled.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Index
member.summary: The index of the point on a polyline point list.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Ratio
member.summary: Ratio: [0, 1], which is always before / (before + after).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Before
member.summary: Arc length before a stop point. Non-negative and less than Length[index].

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.After
member.summary: Arc length after the stop point. Non-negative and less than Length[index].

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Remain
member.summary: Remaining length within a step to hit next stop. Positive to go forward. Negative to go backward.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineHelper
member.summary: Helper class to work with list of points

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineHelper.PathMarch(Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData,System.Double,System.Double,System.Func{Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation,System.Double})
member.summary: March the given polyline with a given interval and output each stop through callback.
member.param: The polyline points to march on.
The arc length to march before stopping at the first point.
The max angle between edges to be considered a corner vertex.
Callback when marching algorithm stop at a point. The callback returns the arc length for next stop. If the asked length is negative, march backwards. If callback returns NaN, finish marching.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineHelper.GetWrappedPolylines(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData},System.Double@)
member.summary: Reorders the given list of polylines so that the polyline with a given arc length in the list is the first. Polylines that preceded this line are concatenated to the end of the list, with the first polyline at the very end.
member.param: A list of polylines.
The arc length in the entire list of polylines at which to find the start line. The arc length into that line is returned in this variable.
member.returns: The reordered and wrapped list.

member.summary: Specifies the unit of thickness.

member.summary: Unit in pixels.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Expression.Media.UnitType.Percent

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1
member.summary: Provides the base class of a source of geometry. Generates and caches the geometry based on the input parameters and the layout bounds.
member.remarks: A typical implementation will extend the UpdateCachedGeometry() to update this.cachedGeometry. This base class will then handle the invalidation, pipeline to the geometry effects, and then cache relative to the layout bounds. An implementation should try to reuse the cached geometry as much as possible to avoid reconstruction in the rendering thread. An implementation can extend the ComputeLogicalBounds to handle Stretch differently.
member.typeparam: The type of geometry source parameter on which the base class is working on.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource
member.summary: Provides an interface to describe the source of a geometry.
member.remarks: This interface is designed to expose the geometry source in a non-generic way. Typical implementation should subclass GeometrySource instead of implementing this interface directly.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.InvalidateGeometry(Microsoft.Expression.Media.InvalidateGeometryReasons)
member.summary: Notifies that the geometry has been invalidated because of external changes.
member.remarks: Geometry is typically invalidated when parameters are changed. If any geometry has been invalidated externally, the geometry will be recomputed even if the layout bounds change.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.UpdateGeometry(Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySourceParameters,System.Windows.Rect)
member.summary: Update the geometry using the given parameters and the layout bounds. Returns false if nothing has been updated.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.Geometry
member.summary: Gets or sets the resulting geometry after the latest UpdateGeometry().

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.LogicalBounds
member.summary: Gets the bounding box where the geometry should stretch to. The actual geometry might be smaller or larger than this. should already take stroke thickness and stretch into consideration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.LayoutBounds
member.summary: Gets the actual bounds of FrameworkElement. includes logical bounds, stretch, and stroke thickness.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.cachedGeometry
member.summary: Specifics the geometry from the previous geometry effect process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.InvalidateGeometry(Microsoft.Expression.Media.InvalidateGeometryReasons)
member.summary: Notifies that the geometry has been invalidated because of external changes.
member.remarks: The geometry is typically invalidated when parameters are changed. If any geometry has been invalidated externally, the geometry will be recomputed regardless if the layout bounds change.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.UpdateGeometry(Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySourceParameters,System.Windows.Rect)
member.summary: Update the geometry based on the given parameters and layoutBounds. Returns false if the geometry hasn't been changed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.UpdateCachedGeometry(`0)
member.summary: Extends the way to provide geometry by implementing this function. Returns true when any of the geometry is changed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.ComputeLogicalBounds(System.Windows.Rect,Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySourceParameters)
member.summary: Extends the way to handle stretch mode. The default is to always use Stretch.Fill and center stroke.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.ApplyGeometryEffect(Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySourceParameters,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Apply the geometry effect when dirty or forced and update this.Geometry. Otherwise, keep this.Geometry as this.cachedGeometry.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.Geometry
member.summary: Gets or sets the resulting geometry after the latest UpdateGeometry().

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.LogicalBounds
member.summary: Gets the bounding box that the geometry should stretch to. The actual geometry might be smaller or larger than this. should already take stroke thickness and stretch into consideration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1.LayoutBounds
member.summary: Gets the actual bounds of FrameworkElement. includes logical bounds, stretch and stroke thickness.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ArcGeometrySource.ComputeLogicalBounds(System.Windows.Rect,Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySourceParameters)
member.summary: Arc recognizes Stretch.None as the same as Stretch.Fill, assuming aspect ratio = 1:1.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ArcGeometrySource.NormalizeThickness(Microsoft.Expression.Media.IArcGeometrySourceParameters)
member.summary: Normalize thickness, both relative to the bounding box and the absolute pixel. Relative thickness = 0 -> full circle radius or clamped. Relative thickness = 1 -> shrank to a dot, or degenerated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ArcGeometrySource.UpdateZeroAngleGeometry(System.Boolean,System.Double)
member.summary: The arc is degenerated to a line pointing to center / normal inward.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ArcGeometrySource.ComputeAngleRanges(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compute a list of angle pairs, defining the ranges in which arc sample should locate. The return value have 2, 4, or 6 double values, each pair defines a range and they are in the order to span the angles from given start to end angles. The ranges will break at the self-intersect angle. If input start/end are within the invalid range between self intersect angle, it will be moved to neighboring self intersect.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ArcGeometrySource.EnsureFirstQuadrant(System.Double)
member.summary: Move angle to 0-90 range.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ArcGeometrySource.SyncPieceWiseInnerCurves(System.Windows.Media.PathFigure,System.Int32,System.Windows.Point@,System.Double[])
member.summary: Compute all pieces of inner curves with each pair of input angles, and connect them with poly Bezier segments. The new segments are output to given figure.Segments list from the given index. The start point is output seperately.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ArcGeometrySource.ComputeOneInnerCurve(System.Double,System.Double,System.Windows.Rect,System.Double)
member.summary: Compute one piece of inner curve with given angle range, and output one piece of smooth curve in format of poly Beizer semgents.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ArcGeometrySource.InnerCurveSelfIntersect(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compute the parameter (angle) of the self-intersect point for given ellipse with given thickness. The result is always in first quadrant, and might be 0 or 90 indicating no self-intersect. Basic algorithm is to binary search for the angle that sample point is not in first quadrant.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometryEffect
member.summary: Provides the base class for GeometryEffect that transforms a geometry into another geometry.
member.remarks: This class provides the basic implementation of processing the rendered geometry of a IShape before it's passed to rendering. A typical implementation will extend the virtual function to transform the input geometry. is typically attached to as an attached property and activated when geometry is updated. The of a will replace the rendered geometry in .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometryEffect.GetGeometryEffect(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Gets the geometry effect as an attached property on a given dependency object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometryEffect.SetGeometryEffect(System.Windows.DependencyObject,Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometryEffect)
member.summary: Sets the geometry effect as an attached property on a given dependency object.

member.summary: Makes a deep copy of the using its current values.

member.summary: Makes a deep copy of the geometry effect. Implements CloneCurrentValue in Silverlight.
member.returns: A clone of the current instance of the geometry effect.

member.returns: Returns true when two effects render with the same appearance.

member.returns: Returns false if nothing has been changed.

member.summary: Extends how the shape is drawn with creating geometry source.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.InvalidateGeometry(Microsoft.Expression.Media.InvalidateGeometryReasons)
member.summary: Invalidates the geometry for a . After the invalidation, the will recompute the geometry, which will occur asynchronously.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.MeasureOverride(System.Windows.Size)
member.summary: Provides the behavior for the Measure portion of Silverlight layout pass. Classes can override this method to define their own Measure pass behavior.
member.returns: The size that this object determines it requires during layout, based on its calculations of child object allotted sizes, or possibly on other considerations such as fixed container size.
member.param: The available size that this object can provide to child objects. Infinity () can be specified as a value to indicate that the object will size to whatever content is available.
member.remarks:
In WPF, measure override works from Shape.DefiningGeometry which is not always as expected see bug 99497 for details where WPF is not having correct measure by default.
In Silverlight, measure override on Path does not work the same as primitive shape works.
We should return the smallest size this shape can correctly render without clipping. By default a shape can render as small as a dot, therefore returning the strokethickness.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.ArrangeOverride(System.Windows.Size)
member.summary: Provides the behavior for the Arrange portion of Silverlight layout pass. Classes can override this method to define their own Arrange pass behavior.
member.returns: The actual size used once the element is arranged in layout.
member.param: The final area within the parent that this object should use to arrange itself and its children.
member.remarks: will recompute the Geometry when it's invalidated and update the RenderedGeometry and GeometryMargin.
